messageBody:
Hi,

I'm back with my AllTests class. I made the suggested changes and I did some
extensive testing.
First, I tried to do the test with junit.servletui.TestRunner and I get the
same errors as before, even with the sample I got those errors.
Executing it from the commandline with junit.ui.TestRunner works fine.
However using the same with the sample creates the following errors:
Exceptions in the junit.samples.AllTests:
executing java junit.samples.AllTests
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoSuchMethodError
at junit.tests.AllTests.suite(AllTests.java:18)
at junit.samples.AllTests.suite(AllTests.java:18)
at junit.samples.AllTests.main(AllTests.java:12)
java junit.textui.TestRunner junit.samples.AllTests
Could not invoke the suite() method

It is essential for us to make it work from a servlet. Does the servletui
work different from the others and if so, how can we make this work or is
there an example that can point us to the right direction?

thanx,
Patrick.

-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
Sent: dinsdag 22 mei 2001 16:36
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Testing all


--- Ghielli Patrick <Patrick.Ghielli@...> wrote:
> Hi all,
>
> I have written the following class to execute all my tests (only a
> few since
> we're just starting). I copied most of it from some example. It does
> not
> really work, however. If I include the constructor I get the error
> that
> there are no tests in AllTest. When I exclude the constructor I get
> the
> error that the class has no public constructor. Is there anyone that
> can
> shed a light on this problem.
>
> thanx and greetz,
> Patrick.
>
>
> import junit.framework.*;
>
> public class AllTests {
>
> public AllTests(String testname){
> //super(testname);
> }
>
> public static void main(String args[]){
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
> }
>
> public static Test suite(){
> TestSuite t_suite= new TestSuite("All User tests");
> t_suite.addTest( UserServletTests.suite());
> t_suite.addTest( new TestSuite(UserServletTests.class));
> t_suite.addTest( UserTests.suite());
> t_suite.addTest( TestUserLogon.suite());
> t_suite.addTest( RegisterTest.suite());
> t_suite.addTest( junit.tests.AllTests.suite());
> return t_suite;
> }
> }
>

In the sample AllTests.java, the intent of the line

suite.addTest(junit.tests.AllTests.suite());

is to add the AllTests class in a *different* package. Notice that the
sample is in the junit.samples packages, rather than the junit.tests
package.

In your case, you'll either want to remove this line or redefine it to
add an AllTests class from another package.

Mike
